text: <extra_id_0> Cylindromatosis <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) protein was originally identified as a tumour suppressor involved in familial cylindromatosis [ 63 ] .

<extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is also involved , however , in diverse physiological processes ranging from immunity and inflammation to cell cycle progression , spermatogenesis , and osteoclastogenesis ( reviewed in [ 64 ] ) .

<extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a <extra_id_0> deubiquitinating enzyme <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that negatively regulates NF-kappaB signalling initiated by TNFR , <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and T-cell receptor stimulation ( reviewed in [ 64 ] ) ( Figure 1 ) , by deubiquitina-ting several NF-kappaB signalling proteins including <extra_id_0> NEMO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Many of these are also targeted by <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and it is still not clear why the cell needs <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as well as <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to control NF-kappaB activation .

As <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is only expressed in many cell types upon stimulation , it has been suggested that this protein mainly regulates later phases of NF-kappaB signalling , whereas <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> would regulate constitutive and early signalling .
In addition , their relative activity might also be cell-type dependent [ 64 ] .

Interestingly , <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been shown to negatively regulate <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signalling and osteoclastogenesis in mice [ 65 ] .
Mice with a genetic deficiency of <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have aberrant osteoclast differentiation and develop severe osteoporosis .
Osteoclast precursors of these mice are hyper - responsive to <extra_id_0> RANKL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced differentiation and produce more and larger osteoclasts .

<extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is markedly upregulated under conditions of <extra_id_0> RANKL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced osteoclastogenesis and is recruited to ubiquitinated <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> via the <extra_id_0> ubiquitin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding adaptor protein <extra_id_0> p62 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also known as <extra_id_0> sequestosome 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) [ 65 ] , followed by the <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated deubiquitination of <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

In this context , it is worth mentioning that transgenic mice expressing a mutated form of <extra_id_0> p62 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also display abnormal osteoclastogenesis and develop progressive bone loss [ 66 ] .

These findings suggest that <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated inhibi-tion of <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappaB signalling plays a key role in the negative regulation of osteoclastogenesis and indicate <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a potential genetic factor involved in the pathology of bone disorders such as RA .
